importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the news report indicates the current status of the flooding crisis in Mexico, reflecting the ongoing impact and response efforts as of that day.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The flooding events occurred last week, which is critical for understanding the temporal context of the disaster and the timing of the response efforts.

keyTakeAways: At least 64 people have died in Mexico due to heavy rains and flooding in five states.
The National Civil Protection Coordination (CNPC) chief, Laura Velazquez Alzua, reported 65 people still missing.
The states most affected are Veracruz (29 deaths), Hidalgo (21 deaths), Puebla (13 deaths), and Queretaro (1 death).
Forty-three people are missing in Hidalgo, 18 in Veracruz, and four in Puebla.
Thousands of military troops, including the Mexican Army, Air Force, and National Guard, have been deployed to assist with rescue and relief operations.
More than 80% of electricity supply has been restored across five states after approximately 263,000 users lost power.
The heavy rainfall was attributed to the remnants of Hurricane Priscilla and Tropical Rainstorm Raymond, causing rivers to rise and trigger floods and landslides.
The heaviest rainfall was recorded in Cerro Azul, Veracruz (280mm) and Cuetzalan del Progreso, Puebla (286mm).
The Mexican government acknowledged a lack of early meteorological warnings indicating the extreme rainfall intensity.
Hundreds of thousands of homes have been affected, with some near rivers reportedly 'practically disappeared'.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Heavy rains from the remnants of Hurricane Priscilla and Tropical Rainstorm Raymond caused widespread flooding and landslides in five Mexican states, resulting in at least 64 deaths and 65 people still missing. The states most affected were Veracruz (29 deaths), Hidalgo (21 deaths), Puebla (13 deaths), and Queretaro (1 death). The heaviest rainfall occurred in Cerro Azul and Cuetzalan del Progreso, with over 280mm recorded. Thousands of military personnel, including the Army, Air Force, and National Guard, were deployed to deliver food, clean water, and medical aid. Over 263,000 residents lost power, and nearly 400 repair workers restored over 80% of electricity. The government acknowledged a lack of early warning signs for the extreme rainfall, raising concerns about disaster preparedness and alert systems.
title: Mexico flooding death toll rises to 64, with dozens still missing
